abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Rehabilitation Credit for
            Mongolia achieved a satisfactory outcome amidst a background
            of economic crisis. Mongolia experienced enormous supply
            shocks in 1991 due to the disruption in the flow of imports
            and the collapse of traditional export markets in the former
            Soviet Union and Council for Mutual Economic Assistance.
            Exceptional arrangements were made for procurement and
            disbursement given Mongolia's high proportion of trade
            with the Commonwealth of Independent States. The project
            successfully supplied urgently needed inputs and contributed
            to the diversification of Mongolia's trade. Moreover,
            the quality of inputs from nontraditional suppliers was
            considerably improved. This had an important demonstration
            effect in the sectors concerned. The project proceeded on
            schedule throughout the early stages of the cycle, but
            procurement delays required extension of the closing date to
            June 30, 1994. Communication and cooperation between the
            Borrower and IDA were satisfactory, as was Borrower
            compliance with credit covenants. Four main lessons emerged
            from this project. First, rapid disbursement is greatly
            facilitated by a well-prepared procurement timetable and
            monitoring system and the appointment of procurement
            advisors prior to negotiations and Board preparation.
            Second, a project of this type can have valuable long-term
            benefits if attention is paid in design and implementation
            to developing the Borrower's institutional capacity.
            Third, emergency assistance of this nature is most effective
            when combined with donor coordination to address broader
            macroeconomic and sectorial concerns. Fourth, the objectives
            of counterpart fund management and emergency assistance are
            difficult to reconcile in transitional economies where
            ability to pay is constrained by adjustment processes.

18155411.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific
18155411.theme: Other financial and private sector development,Infrastructure services for private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal objective of the Economic
            Rehabilitation Credit is to help rehabilitate, maintain and
            operate priority sectors of Mongolia's economy. It
            constitutes part of an immediate response by the
            international community to the country's short-term
            economic difficulties. The project finances equipment,
            materials, spare parts, vehicles and other inputs needed for
            key agriculture, energy (electric power, coal mining and
            petroleum products), and transport sectors, to sustain
            economic performance and output.
